results.name: Any number n can be written uniquely in the form n = 2^k_1 - 2^k_2 + 2^k_3 - ... + 2^k_{2r+1} where the signs alternate, there are an odd number of terms, and k_1 > k_2 > k_3 > ... > k_{2r+1} >= 0; sequence gives number of terms 2r+1.
comment: 2^k_1 is smallest power of 2 that is >= n.
The first Mathematica program computes the sequence for numbers 1 to 2^m. - _T. D. Noe_, Jul 15 2002
Add 1 to every other terms of A005811. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Jan 14 2017
reference: P. Bachmann, Niedere Zahlentheorie (1902, 1910), reprinted Chelsea, NY, 1968, vol. 2, pp. 61-62.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..16384
S. Kropf, S. Wagner, q-Quasiadditive functions, arXiv:1605.03654 [math.CO], 2016. See section "The number of runs and the Gray code".
Index entries for sequences related to binary expansion of n
mathematica: Needs["DiscreteMath`Combinatorica`"]; sumit[s_List] := Module[{i, ss=0}, Do[If[OddQ[i], ss+=s[[i]], ss-=s[[i]]], {i, Length[s]}]; ss]; m=8; powers=Table[2^i, {i, 0, m}]; lst=Table[0, {2^m}]; sets={}; Do[sets=Union[sets, KSubsets[powers, i]], {i, 1, m+1, 2}]; Do[t=sets[[i]]; lst[[sumit[t]]]=Length[t], {i, Length[sets]}]; lst
